qas.question: Why was this drug put on shelves?

context: The firm continued to pressure Kelsey and the agency to approve the application—until <a1_0><b11_0>November <a5_0>1961<b11_0/><a5_0/><a1_0/>, when the drug was pulled off the German market because of its <a4_0>association with grave <a6_0>congenital abnormalities<a6_0/><a4_0/>. Several thousand newborns in Europe and elsewhere suffered the teratogenic effects of thalidomide. Though the drug was never approved in the USA, the firm distributed <a7_0>Kevadon<a7_0/> to over 1,000 physicians there <a3_0><b13_0><b14_0>under the guise of investigational use<b14_0/><b13_0/><a3_0/>. <a0_0><a8_0><b10_0>Over 20,000<b10_0/><a8_0/><a0_0/> Americans received thalidomide in this "study," including 624 pregnant patients, and <a2_0><b12_0>about <a9_0>17<b12_0/><a9_0/><a2_0/> known newborns suffered the effects of the drug.[citation needed]
